channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: HBOS ex-bosses may get City bans
item.description: The Banking Standards Commission calls for three former HBOS bosses to be barred from City jobs after a "colossal failure" of management.

item.title: Osborne's Philpott remarks spark row
item.description: Chancellor George Osborne's remarks on whether the state "subsidises" the lifestyles of people like Mick Philpott, who killed six of his children, sparks a political row.

item.title: Three jailed over Derby fire deaths
item.description: Mick Philpott receives a life sentence while his wife and friend are each jailed for 17 years for killing six children in a house fire in Derby.

item.title: Film critic Roger Ebert dies at 70
item.description: Renowned American film critic Roger Ebert - famed for his thumbs-up or down reviews - dies at 70 after a long battle with cancer.

item.title: Ban fears serious Korea consequences
item.description: UN chief Ban Ki-moon says he is concerned North Korea's rhetoric has gone too far, after reports it has moved a mid-range missile to its east coast.

item.title: Queen honoured with Bafta award
item.description: The Queen receives an honorary Bafta for her support for British film at a glittering ceremony - and is described as "the most memorable Bond girl yet".

item.title: Hewlett-Packard chairman steps down
item.description: Hewlett-Packard announces a boardroom shake-up that includes its chairman Raymond Lane stepping down.

item.title: Greek club teen 'unlawfully killed'
item.description: A verdict of unlawful killing is returned at the inquest into the death of a Cardiff teenager who died after being punched in a Greek nightclub in 2007.

item.title: Detective jailed for selling drugs
item.description: A corrupt detective found guilty of stealing massive amounts of seized drugs and conspiring to sell them back on to the streets is jailed for 23 years.

item.title: US Craigslist killer to be executed
item.description: An Ohio man convicted of luring men to their deaths with fake job ads on the Craigslist website will face the death penalty, a judge rules.

item.title: UK must keep Trident - Cameron
item.description: David Cameron says the UK would be "foolish" to abandon Trident in the face of the potential threat of nuclear attack from North Korea and Iran.

item.title: Brain scans can 'read our dreams'
item.description: Scientists have found a way to read people's dreams using brain scans, a new study suggests.

item.title: Facebook releases Android 'home'
item.description: Facebook releases software that puts content from the social network on the home screen of Android phones.

item.title: Londoners claim Lake District name
item.description: The Lake District is being urged to give up its title - by a group from south London which is claiming the name.

item.title: No smoking signs made 'friendlier'
item.description: Blackpool Council give no smoking signs in the town's parks a "friendlier design" following concerns from local residents.

item.title: First Cyprus plan 'not smart' - ECB
item.description: The initial plan to make small savers pay for the Cyprus bailout was "not smart" the European Central Bank president has said.

item.title: VIDEO: World Bank chief sees end to poverty
item.description: Jim Yong Kim is urging direct action to help more than a billion people benefit from growth.

item.title: Unite calls for general strike
item.description: Britain's biggest trade union, Unite, is calling for a 24-hour general strike against austerity measures.

item.title: UK concern at Saudi paralysis ruling
item.description: The UK urges Saudi Arabia not to carry out a "grotesque" sentencing of paralysis for a man as punishment for paralysing another man.

item.title: Five deaths from new China bird flu
item.description: The World Health Organization says there have now been five deaths in China from a new bird flu virus.

item.title: Roche to release all Tamiflu data
item.description: The drug company Roche has announced that it will give researchers access to all its trial data for the influenza drug Tamiflu, the BMJ reports.

item.title: Adoption changes 'a reckless gamble'
item.description: Plans to strip some English councils of their role in the adoption process would be a "reckless gamble", the Local Government Association says.

item.title: Failing colleges face intervention
item.description: Underperforming further education colleges in England face a tougher regime, as the government launches its skills strategy.

item.title: Hack attacks hit Bitcoin value
item.description: Online services and exchanges dealing in Bitcoins have been hit by hack attacks that led to a drop in the value of the virtual currency.

item.title: Anonymous 'hacks' North Korea pages
item.description: Websites and social networking profiles linked to North Korea have been hacked and vandalised, hacktivist group Anonymous claims.

item.title: Mars rover takes some downtime
item.description: With Mars moving behind the Sun as viewed from Earth, Nasa's Curiosity rover is about to enter three weeks of low activity.

item.title: Exhaled breath is unique fingerprint
item.description: Scientists report that compounds present in breath are unique to individuals - a "breathprint" - and could be exploited in a range of medical applications.

item.title: Siouxsie tops Ono's Meltdown line-up
item.description: Siouxsie Sioux, Marianne Faithfull and Iggy and the Stooges head a list of acts chosen by Yoko Ono to perform at this year's Meltdown Festival

item.title: Ballet star exits Midnight Express
item.description: Ballet star Sergei Polunin is replaced in the cast of Midnight Express just days before it is due to open at the Coliseum in London.

item.title: Can I have no job or money and still be middle class?
item.description: I’m 25. I’m a graduate. I’m about to be unemployed. I’m a London suburbanite. And I have no savings. So what class am I?

item.title: 'Of course I'm elite - I have red shoes'
item.description: There are now seven social groupings in the UK, so what has the reaction been from those who are no longer upper, middle or working class?

item.title: Tottenham 2-2 FC Basel
item.description: Tottenham fight back from two goals down to draw with Basel in the first leg of their Europa League quarter-final.

item.title: Chelsea 3-1 Rubin Kazan
item.description: Fernando Torres scores twice as Chelsea establish a first-leg lead over Rubin Kazan in the Europa League quarter-final.

item.title: Benfica 3-1 Newcastle
item.description: Newcastle suffer a second-half collapse in the first leg of their Europa League quarter-final against Benfica.

item.title: Inside the world's greatest race
item.description: Saddle up for an insider's view of the world's most famous horse race

item.title: Armstrong withdraws from swim meet
item.description: Disgraced cyclist Lance Armstrong withdraws from the US Masters swimming championships after an objection from Fina.

item.title: Hospital 'placed money above care'
item.description: A hospital where women with breast cancer were given faulty test results - and so may not have had the best treatment - prioritised money over patient care, a report says.

item.title: Man shot dead during police raid
item.description: A man is shot dead during a police drugs raid in the Clayton area of Bradford.

item.title: Brutal murderers jailed for 23 years
item.description: A man and woman who made a young girl collect a hammer and knife before brutally killing their victim in front of her are jailed for life.

item.title: William and Kate on Scottish visit
item.description: The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge visit Glasgow as part of a two-day trip to Scotland.

item.title: Airport security stepped up for G8
item.description: The police are warning of potential disruption in and around Belfast International Airport because of the G8 summit in June.

item.title: Family battled to save blaze victim
item.description: The family of a woman who died in a house fire in west Belfast on Wednesday night tried desperately to save her.

item.title: Birthday balloons for missing April
item.description: The family of April Jones, who has been missing for more than six months, remember her birthday by releasing hundreds of pink balloons near her home.

item.title: Osborne 'unaware' of parking error
item.description: Chancellor George Osborne did not realise a car he was travelling in was parked in a disabled bay at a motorway service station, the BBC understands.

item.title: Mozambican ex-rebels in police raid
item.description: At least five people in Mozambique are killed after members of the opposition party Renamo, an ex-rebel movement, attack a police post.

item.title: Mass grave exhumed in Ivory Coast
item.description: Ivory Coast's government starts to exhume the mass graves of people killed in the violence that hit the country after the disputed 2010 election.

item.title: Japan unveils massive stimulus plan
item.description: Japan's central bank surprises markets with the size of its latest stimulus package, as it tries to spur growth and end years of falling prices.

item.title: 'Nine dead' in India axe attack
item.description: A man goes on a rampage with an axe in a village in central India, killing four women and five girls, according to police.

item.title: France's Hollande fights tax scandal
item.description: A financial scandal threatens France's President Hollande, after it emerged that his former party treasurer invested in the Cayman Islands tax haven.

item.title: Rijksmuseum set for grand reopening
item.description: Inside Amsterdam's beautifully restored Rijksmuseum, which reopens to the public next week after 10 years.

item.title: Argentina floods 'a catastrophe'
item.description: More bodies are found in La Plata and Buenos Aires, with dozens confirmed dead in what locals say is the Argentine region's worst catastrophe.

item.title: Seven Cuban ballet dancers defect
item.description: Seven young ballet dancers from Cuba have defected while on tour in Mexico

item.title: West Bank clashes follow funeral
item.description: Palestinian protesters clash with Israeli forces in the West Bank city of Hebron following the funeral of a Palestinian prisoner who died in Israeli jail.

item.title: UN halts Gaza food aid after attack
item.description: The UN says it is suspending all its food distribution centres in the Gaza Strip after protesters angered by aid cutbacks stormed one of its compounds.

item.title: Connecticut signs landmark gun law
item.description: The governor of the US state where 20 young children were shot dead at school in December signs into law some of America's strictest gun control measures.

item.title: Bonus for fired US basketball coach
item.description: The former US college basketball coach fired for abusing players and screaming homophobic slurs receives a $100,000 (£65,802) bonus on the way out.

item.title: Day in pictures: 4 April 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 4 April

item.title: In pictures: Argentina's deadly floods
item.description: More than 50 people die in Argentina floods

item.title: Your pictures: Early morning
item.description: Readers' photos on the theme early morning

item.title: In pictures: Syria's injured refugees
item.description: Refugees from Syria begin to rebuild their lives

item.title: In pictures: Inside India's oldest Muslim university
item.description: Inside India's oldest Muslim university

item.title: Day in pictures: 3 April 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 3 April

item.title: Week in pictures: 23-29 March 2013
item.description: A selection of news photos from this week

item.title: In pictures: Easter Sunday
item.description: Celebrations across the world

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: The health secretary has set out the government's response to the Stafford Hospital inquiry.

item.title: VIDEO: New video of Luther King killer in custody
item.description: On the 45th anniversary of the death of Martin Luther King, previously unseen footage has been released showing his killer in police custody.

item.title: VIDEO: Babies and basketballs as royals visit Glasgow
item.description: The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge visit Glasgow as part of a two-day trip to Scotland.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Irony' as female judge jails Philpott
item.description: A female judge has sentenced Mick Philpott to life for killing six of his children in a fire at his Derby house, the editor of the local paper said there was a "delicious irony that a woman has finally told Mick Philpott what to do".

item.title: VIDEO: How a US liberal learned to love guns
item.description: Dan Baum, author of Gun Guys: A Road Trip, tells the BBC why as a liberal Democrat who loves guns, he is considered a "very weird hybrid".

item.title: VIDEO: Chair 'grows like popcorn'
item.description: Belgian designer Carl de Smet discusses his experiments with smart foam technology, which allows him to 'bake' furniture so it assembles itself.

item.title: VIDEO: Facebook releases Android 'home'
item.description: Facebook releases software that puts content from the social network on the home page of Android phones.

item.title: VIDEO: Rijksmuseum: Rembrandt centre stage
item.description: Rijksmuseum's director of collections, Taco Dibbits, takes the BBC's Will Gompertz for a tour of the re-furbished exhibition space in Amsterdam.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Lawnmower sheep' to graze in Paris parks
item.description: Paris city council launches a pilot project that, if successful, will see sheep replacing lawnmowers in the French capital's public spaces.

item.title: A 'classic case' of domestic violence
item.description: What does the Philpotts case tell us about domestic violence?

item.title: In Pictures: Queen receives Bafta
item.description: Queen receives honorary Bafta at star-studded Windsor event

item.title: How are goths and emos defined?
item.description: How are ‘goths’ and ‘emos’ and ‘metallers’ defined?

item.title: How did neo-Nazi prison gangs become so powerful?
item.description: How did US neo-Nazi prison gangs become so powerful?

item.title: 'Death risk' in measles outbreak
item.description: Why experts fear there could be a death

item.title: Crowds flock to opening day of races
item.description: The hats and outfits catching the eye on Aintree's opening day

item.title: Grand National sweepstake kit
item.description: All you need for your own lucky dip for Saturday's Grand National

item.title: Surviving on only British-made goods
item.description: How family is faring in quest to buy home-grown goods

item.title: Slovenia seeks to dismiss 'another Cyprus hysteria'
item.description: Slovenia's leaders dismiss bailout 'hysteria', writes Nick Thorpe

item.title: Does SSE fine match the offence?
item.description: Is fine for misleading customers too lenient, asks Robert Peston
